PCTR questions

Source: vignettes/articles/pctr-questions.Rmd
pctr-questions.Rmd

Here I ask the questions I have when I characterize the PCTR data and code.

library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = TRUE)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
library(tiltIndicator)

packageVersion("tiltIndicator")
#> [1] '0.0.0.9022'

1. Joining by redundant columns

Questions:

  • 1.1. We call *_join() with by = c("activity_product_uuid", "ei_activity", "unit") and Tilman suggested we might remove "ei_activity" and "unit". Do we expect them to be always redundant with the groups defined by "activity_product_uuid" alone? Or do you mean they are redundant in this specific toy dataset?

2. Edge case with too few co2 data

pctr_score_copmanies() returns 3 rows for each company (regardless the number of rows per company). This seems expected.

one_company <- pctr_companies |> filter(company_id %in% first(company_id))
pctr_ecoinvent_co2 |>
  pctr_score_activities() |>
  pctr_score_companies(one_company)
#> # A tibble: 3 Ã— 5
#>   company_id                           score share_all share_unit share_unit_sec
#>   <chr>                                <chr>     <dbl>      <dbl>          <dbl>
#> 1 powerstartmanufacturinggmbh_0000000â€¦ high       0.25       0.5            0.5 
#> 2 powerstartmanufacturinggmbh_0000000â€¦ mediâ€¦      0.25       0.25           0.25
#> 3 powerstartmanufacturinggmbh_0000000â€¦ low        0.5        0.25           0.25

another_company <- pctr_companies |> filter(company_id %in% last(company_id))
two_companies <- bind_rows(one_company, another_company)
pctr_ecoinvent_co2 |>
  pctr_score_activities() |>
  pctr_score_companies(two_companies)
#> # A tibble: 6 Ã— 5
#>   company_id                           score share_all share_unit share_unit_sec
#>   <chr>                                <chr>     <dbl>      <dbl>          <dbl>
#> 1 powerstartmanufacturinggmbh_0000000â€¦ high       0.25      0.5           0.5   
#> 2 powerstartmanufacturinggmbh_0000000â€¦ mediâ€¦      0.25      0.25          0.25  
#> 3 powerstartmanufacturinggmbh_0000000â€¦ low        0.5       0.25          0.25  
#> 4 mbdgmbh_00000004773428001            high       0.25      0.438         0.688 
#> 5 mbdgmbh_00000004773428001            mediâ€¦      0.5       0.375         0.25  
#> 6 mbdgmbh_00000004773428001            low        0.25      0.188         0.0625

But the number number of rows in the co2 data can be such that the output seems useless and you get no warning.

too_few_co2_rows <- pctr_ecoinvent_co2 |> slice(1)
too_few_co2_rows
#> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 5
#>   co2_footprint sec       unit          activity_product_uuid        ei_activity
#>           <dbl> <chr>     <chr>         <chr>                        <chr>      
#> 1          4.33 Transport metric ton*km 0a242b09-772a-5edf-8e82-9cbâ€¦ transport,â€¦

too_few_co2_rows |>
  pctr_score_activities() |>
  pctr_score_companies(one_company)
#> # A tibble: 3 Ã— 5
#>   company_id                           score share_all share_unit share_unit_sec
#>   <chr>                                <chr>     <dbl>      <dbl>          <dbl>
#> 1 powerstartmanufacturinggmbh_0000000â€¦ high       0.25       0.25           0.25
#> 2 powerstartmanufacturinggmbh_0000000â€¦ mediâ€¦      0          0              0   
#> 3 powerstartmanufacturinggmbh_0000000â€¦ low        0          0              0

too_few_co2_rows |>
  pctr_score_activities() |>
  pctr_score_companies(two_companies)
#> # A tibble: 6 Ã— 5
#>   company_id                           score share_all share_unit share_unit_sec
#>   <chr>                                <chr>     <dbl>      <dbl>          <dbl>
#> 1 powerstartmanufacturinggmbh_0000000â€¦ high       0.25       0.25           0.25
#> 2 powerstartmanufacturinggmbh_0000000â€¦ mediâ€¦      0          0              0   
#> 3 powerstartmanufacturinggmbh_0000000â€¦ low        0          0              0   
#> 4 mbdgmbh_00000004773428001            high       0          0              0   
#> 5 mbdgmbh_00000004773428001            mediâ€¦      0          0              0   
#> 6 mbdgmbh_00000004773428001            low        0          0              0

Questions:

  • 2.1. Is this output useful?
  • 2.2. Should we allow this output with a warning or throw an error and stop?
